mosqito.sq_metrics.roughness.roughness_dw.roughness_dw module#

roughness_dw(signal, fs=None, overlap=0.5, is_sdt_output=False)[source]#

Returns the roughness according to Daniel and Weber method.

This function computes the global and specific roughness values of a signal sampled at 48 kHz.

Parameters:

  • signal (array_like or DataTime object) – Input time signal in Pa

  • fs (float, optional) – Sampling frequency, can be omitted if the input is a DataTime object. Default to None

  • overlap (float) – Overlapping coefficient for the time windows of 200ms

Returns:

  • R (numpy.array) – Roughness value in [asper]

  • R_spec (numpy.array) – Specific roughness over bark axis

  • bark_axis (numpy.array) – Frequency axis in [bark]

  • time (numpy.array) – Time axis in [s]

Raises:

IndexError – If axis is not a valid axis of a.

See also

roughness_dw_freq

roughness computation from a sound spectrum

Notes

The model consists of a parallel processing structure that is made up of successive stages and calculates intermediate specific roughnesses R_spec, which are summed up to determine the total roughness R.

References

[DW]

P. Daniel and R. Weber, “Psychoacoustical roughness: implementation of an optimized model”, 1997

Examples

>>> from mosqito.sq_metrics import roughness_dw
>>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
>>> import numpy as np
>>> fc=1000
>>> fmod=70
>>> fs=44100
>>> d=0.2
>>> dB=60
>>> time = np.arange(0, d, 1/fs)
>>> stimulus = (0.5 * (1 + np.sin(2 * np.pi * fmod * time))* np.sin(2 * np.pi * fc * time))
>>> rms = np.sqrt(np.mean(np.power(stimulus, 2)))
>>> ampl = 0.00002 * np.power(10, dB / 20) / rms
>>> stimulus = stimulus * ampl
>>> R, R_specific, bark, time = roughness_dw(stimulus, fs=44100, overlap=0)
>>> plt.plot(bark, R_specific)
>>> plt.xlabel("Bark axis [Bark]")
>>> plt.ylabel("Specific roughness [Asper/Bark]")
>>> plt.title("Roughness = " + f"{R[0]:.2f}" + " [Asper]")

(Source code, png, hires.png, pdf)
